items.title: upload_from_galaxy_filesystem() jobs just stay queued forever in Galaxy
items.body: I'm using Bioblend to mass-upload files from various files on the server in S3-mounted buckets into data libraries in our Galaxy system.  The files appear in the libaries, with correct sizes, but remain in "queued" state forever... they cannot be used in histories.  Any ideas why?  The "queued" jobs to upload each file have no assigned job runners.  Other job types run fine....

items.title: HTTP Authentication for Galaxy Server
items.body:
Hello,

Our Galaxy server is setup so that we must authenticate via HTTP basic authentication with a username/password for the system before we can actually access Galaxy and log in with our Galaxy user account. 

How can I specify this when defining a GalaxyInstance? Since without it, I get 401 Unauthorized error.

Thanks.

items.title: export history error
items.body:
I am having an error with the last version of bioblend when I use the 'export_history' method.

When I install bioblend with `pip install bioblend` and use python 3.8.2, it works just fine.
But I need the import_history method added in december 2019.
Since the last release is from august 2019, I installed bioblend this way:
`python3 -m pip install git+https://github.com/galaxyproject/bioblend`

With this version, when I want to get a jeha_id with 'export_history()', the first time, I got the following error:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):

    raise ConnectionError("Unexpected HTTP status code: %s" % r.status_code,

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

    main()
  File "transfert_galaxy_users.py", line 122, in main
    galaxy_ref.download_histories(user,histories_path,args.skip_pending_histories)

items.title: Potential dependency conflicts between bioblend and requests
items.body:
Hi, as shown in the following full dependency graph of  **_bioblend_**, **_bioblend_** requires **_requests >=2.20.0_** ， while the installed version of **_requests-toolbelt_**(0.9.1) requires _**requests >=2.0.1,<3.0.0**_.

According to Pip's _“first found wins”_ installation strategy, _**requests  2.22.0**_ is the actually installed version.  

Although the first found package version _**requests  2.22.0**_ just satisfies the later dependency constraint （_**requests >=2.0.1,<3.0.0**_), it will lead to a build failure once developers release a newer version of requests.

### Dependency tree--------
```
bioblend - 0.13.0
| +- boto(install version:2.49.0 version range:>=2.9.7)
| +- pyyaml(install version:5.2b1 version range:*)
| +- requests(install version:2.22.0 version range:>=2.20.0)
| | +- certifi(install version:2019.9.11 version range:>=2017.4.17)
| | +- chardet(install version:3.0.4 version range:<3.1.0,>=3.0.2)
| | +- idna(install version:2.8 version range:>=2.5,<2.9)
| | +- urllib3(install version:1.25.7 version range:<1.26,>=1.21.1)
| +- requests-toolbelt(install version:0.9.1 version range:>=0.5.1)
| | +- requests(install version:2.22.0 version range:>=2.0.1,<3.0.0)
| | | +- certifi(install version:2019.9.11 version range:>=2017.4.17)
| | | +- chardet(install version:3.0.4 version range:<3.1.0,>=3.0.2)
| | | +- idna(install version:2.8 version range:>=2.5,<2.9)
| | | +- urllib3(install version:1.25.7 version range:<1.26,>=1.21.1)
| +- six(install version:1.13.0 version range:*) 
```

Thanks for your attention.
Best,
Neolith

items.title: Stop supporting Galaxy < 15.03
items.body:
Galaxy 15.03 is the first release exposing its version through the API. Supporting only Galaxy releases for which we can determine the version would make it easier to work with changes in API endpoints and return values.

Opinions @galaxyproject/bioblend ?

items.title: Need to expose history import
items.body: The API is exposed in Galaxy as part of POST to /api/histories, with archive_source and archive_type parameters (https://github.com/galaxyproject/galaxy/blob/dev/lib/galaxy/webapps/galaxy/api/histories.py#L300).

items.title: Release schedule
items.body: Would it be possible to consider releasing more regularly, perhaps in sync with the Galaxy releases? Ok, not many new features since last release, but it would ensure that changes are in a release within 3 months, rather than having to specially request a release.

items.title: 'GalaxyInstance' object has no attribute 'toolshed'
items.body:
I want to automatically populate a Galaxy instance. Following BioBlend docs, I had no issue with other commands, but when trying to install a toolshed repository I cannot have it work as the rest. I tried before ephemeris and ansible-playbook for tool installation, but they are bugged with connection errors and fail [(issue)](https://github.com/galaxyproject/ephemeris/issues/99), so I wanted to try this way. This is some code I used:
```
from bioblend import galaxy
gi = galaxy.GalaxyInstance(url='http://127.0.0.1:8080', key='admin')
hist1 = gi.histories.create_history(name='hist1')  # works

gi.workflows
# <bioblend.galaxy.workflows.WorkflowClient object at 0x7f4b0943e950>
gi.toolshed
# AttributeError: 'GalaxyInstance' object has no attribute 'toolshed'
```
Using `inspect.getmembers(galaxy)`, I see the module `toolshed`, but I cannot have it working. I'd appreciate some help.

I tried on bioblend 0.11.0 and 0.12.00, installed with pip. Running on a dockerized Galaxy, version 18.05.

items.title: Is bioblend concurrency safe?
items.body:
We are running some pipelines through bioblend on Galaxy. Basically our setup loads workflow file, parameters and data into the instance and then waits until the workflow is done (all through bioblend). When we increase the number of concurrent requests sent to the Galaxy instance we get errors that we cannot reproduce when just running a single run on its own. We are wondering if there might be communication issues when doing multiple concurrent runs?

If we work with 10 concurrent workflows being executed, then we don't seem to see the error, but when we move to 20 concurrent executions, we see it.

Maybe it could be an issue with our workflow resolution logic (how do we decide when the workflow is done). If you could give us any advice, it would be great:

https://github.com/ebi-gene-expression-group/galaxy-workflow-executor/blob/feature/consider_paused_jobs_due_to_previous_errors/run_galaxy_workflow.py#L407-L413

The error we see is that the part shown there is lead to believe that all jobs are in "terminal" states when in fact jobs are still running. We don't see this if just sending one or a few executions at the same time (with the same failing datasets).

Thanks!

items.title: Adding tags to many history items
items.body:
Hi,

I needed to create a name tag for ~8000 history items on usegalaxy.eu server. This is possible to do with bioblend, but is non-intuitive and really slow.

My task was to take the name of an item and re-use it as a tag. To do so I have to:

1. Download all ids of the datasets and with them all names:
```
dataset_ids = []
dataset_ids = gi.histories.show_history(id_history)['state_ids']['ok']
for dataset in dataset_ids:
    names_list.append(gi.histories.show_dataset(id_history, dataset)['name'])
```

This is some overhead, and, as written in my other issue opend today, it would be an improvement if an API call to receive the ids and dataset names would exists and I don't have to download all metadata.

2. Add a tag. This is more complicated than I thought. There is this `update_dataset` function but it is not well documented. Once more I had to ask @erasche if I just can write 'tag' as a parameter.Moreover, I wanted to have tags which are inherited and shown in the GUI, in the GUI you can use the hashtag for this `#foo`. Not so in the API, there it needs to be `name:foo`. Again, this is not documented and non-intuitive. Please remove multiple ways to achieve the same result. 

The following code I used:

```
for data_id, name in zip(dataset_ids, names_list):
    gi.histories.update_dataset(id_history, data_id, tags=['name:'+name])
```
Finally, the call of the update function to add ~8000 tags is slow, really slow. With usegalaxy.eu server it took 1 - 2 hours! This performance is not acceptable.

I propose the following API function:
```
add_tag(dataset_id, tag=['', '',], add_as_name_tag=True)
```

Or, for many dataset_ids at once:

```
add_tag(dataset_id_list=[id1, id2, ..., id_n], tag=[['', '',], [],....[]], add_as_name_tag=True)
```


 Best,

Joachim

items.title: Creating a collection, workflow, api calls, and performance
items.body:
Hi,

I have created a collection out of history items. It is possible to this with current bioblend, however, it is not intuitive and really slow. Some short remarks on how I did this, maybe there is a way you can optimize the API. 

First, you need to receive the dataset ids. This can be done via:
```dataset_ids = gi.histories.show_history(id_history)['state_ids']['ok']```
It works, but a) it is really not intuitive to get first a really big dictionary from the server and selecting locally over the keys 'state_ids' and there the status 'ok' the ids of the datasets of a history. Why not providing an API function 'receive_all_dataset_ids' and getting a list of ids back? And b) it is not documented on readthedocs you are able to receive the datasets ids in this way. Without the help of @erasche I wouldn't been able to get this information. And not everyone is having an experienced Galaxy admin sitting in the next office down the hallway.

In my second step I had to order the files by name locally to create two collections: for forward (R1) and reverse (R2) strand files.

```
element_identifiers_r1 = []
element_identifiers_r2 = []
for dataset_id in dataset_ids:
    dataset_dict = gi.histories.show_dataset(id_history, dataset_id)
    if '_R1.' in dataset_dict['name']:
        element_identifiers_r1.append(dataset_dict)
    elif '_R2.' in dataset_dict['name']:
        element_identifiers_r2.append(dataset_dict)

```
Again, it seems not to be intuitive to download each history item one by one with all metadata and using there only the name field. However, I need the full dict to be able to create a collection:

```
collection_description_r1 = {'collection_type': 'list',
 'element_identifiers': element_identifiers_r1,
 'name': 'Forward reads'}
collection_description_r2 = {'collection_type': 'list',
 'element_identifiers': element_identifiers_r2,
 'name': 'Reverse reads'}
``` 

And again, why do I need to download the full metadata information? It would be more intuitive for me as follows:

1. Download all ids + names and only them. This means there need to be two more API functions: Get dataset_ids and get_dataset_names. The order of the elements in the two lists needs to be guaranteed.
2. Instead of a list of dictionaries `element_identifiers` a list of dataset ids would be sufficient. All the rest can be handled on the server side.

And last, to create a new collection:
```gi.histories.create_dataset_collection(id_history, collection_description_r1)```
This is a simple call, however it took for ~4000 elements that should be part of the new collection ~20 - 30 mins with usegalaxy.eu server. (Sorry I cannot re-measure it atm, because the server is down).

After this collection was created, I wanted to check if everything worked as expected. Unfortunately there is only a undocumented way to receive the collection ids. Again @erasche showed me this, but why not add a new API call `get_collection_ids`?

Best,

Joachim

items.title: No input dataset error in invoke_workflow()
items.body:
Hi there,

I am using v0.8.1.  Up until now, I have continued to use the deprecated run_workflow() function, and it has worked fairly well.  As my workflows become more complex (>100 steps), I have run in to a problem where identical workflows are written to a given history several times, followed by bioblend throwing a ConnectionError.  I generally am trying to start 20-40 workflows in the same process, so many of them will be correctly initiated before the error occurs.  Smaller workflows (~50 steps) seems to be fine.

EDIT: Solved first problem by giving VM additional resources (load average was skyrocketing).

So, my thought was to stop using the deprecated run_workflow() in favor of invoke_workflow().  A statement in the documentation made me think this might help my particular situation.  The problem I run in to now is that invoke_workflow() complains that it can't find an expected input step.  Since this works fine with run_workflow, seems strange.  I can see exactly which input dataset is causing problems, but I can't figure out why the problems are occurring.

> bioblend.ConnectionError: Unexpected HTTP status code: 400: {"err_msg": "Workflow cannot be run because an expected input step '43580' has no input dataset.", "err_code": 0}

Every time I've seen this in the past, it was a very easy fix, and generally has something to do with the workflow not being strung together correctly.  Unfortunately, doesn't seem to be the case this time.  Any thoughts?

@afgane I've updated `CHANGELOG.md`, if you want to take a look. Anything outstanding from your side (apart from open pull requests)?

```bash
# Cleanup
find . -name '*.pyc' -delete
rm -rf dist/
# Install latest versions of pip, setuptools and twine in a virtualenv
[ -f .venv/bin/activate ] || virtualenv .venv
. .venv/bin/activate

# Create files in dist/

python setup.py bdist_wheel
twine upload dist/*
```

items.title: Update Testing to pytest instead of nosetest.
API key being send in URL query
items.body: I've been testing out the Galaxy API via bioblend in order to pull data into Galaxy automatically from a mass spectrometer. I noticed in testing on a temporary Galaxy instance that requests are sending my API key as part of the URL query string. This is a pretty big (!!!) security vulnerability for a production server. Is there a way to put the key within the encrypted payload, such as in the HTTP headers (see for example the Basespace API)?

items.title: Move bioblend tests into the bioblend module.

Upload all files in the specified subdirectory of the Galaxy library import directory to a library.

# Add an option to the library upload form which allows administrators to upload a directory of files.

items.title: can't download datasets
items.body:
I noticed an issue when I tried downloading small datasets from our server. I would get the error:

```
Could not get display data for dataset: HistoryDatasetAssociation is not accessible by user
```

I tested this on our server in Freiburg.
Galaxy: release_15.10
bioblend: 0.7.0 (also tested 0.5.3, 0.6.1)

I'm not sure if it's a configuration issue, but I can circumvent this error when I change the way that the download_dataset builds the request and includes the api_key as argument.
If I change the download_dataset method in the file:

```
galaxy/datasets/__init__.py
```

the way the request is built from:

```
r = requests.get(url, verify=self.gi.verify)
```

to

```
r = self.gi.make_get_request(url)
```

it works and I can download files.

items.title: Some ToolShedClient functions give a 404
items.body:
Bioblend doesn't seem to behave as the manual (at page http://bioblend.readthedocs.org/en/latest/api_docs/galaxy/all.html?highlight=toolshedclient#bioblend.galaxy.toolshed.ToolShedClient) describes. When I run the following code: ``` from bioblend.galaxy import GalaxyInstance import bioblend bioblend.__version__ >>> '0.6.1' from bioblend import toolshed gi = GalaxyInstance(url='127.0.0.1', key='') tsc = bioblend.toolshed.repositories.ToolShedClient(gi) tsc.repository_revisions() ``` It gives the following 404: ``` bioblend.galaxy.client.ConnectionError: GET: error 404: '\r\n Not Found\r\n \r\n

Not Found

\r\n

The resource could not be found.\r\n
No route for /api/repository_revisions\r\n

\r\n
\r\n
WSGI Server
\r\n \r\n\r\n', 0 attempts left: None ``` Could it be that the url has moved from: ``` gi.url + '/repository_revisions' ``` https://github.com/galaxyproject/bioblend/blob/master/bioblend/toolshed/repositories/__init__.py#L236 https://github.com/galaxyproject/bioblend/blob/master/bioblend/toolshed/repositories/__init__.py#L290 to: ``` gi.url + '/tool_shed_repositories' ``` --- When I continue with the following code: ``` tsc.get_repositories() ``` It also gives a 404 error: ``` bioblend.galaxy.client.ConnectionError: GET: error 404: '\r\n Not Found\r\n \r\n

Not Found

\r\n

The resource could not be found.\r\n
No route for /api/repositories\r\n

\r\n
\r\n
WSGI Server
\r\n \r\n\r\n', 0 attempts left: None ``` Similarly, `tsc.show_repository('65d5559f7c7e2cb9')` results in a 404 to `/api/repositories/65d5559f7c7e2cb9`. I think this url should be `/api/tool_shed_repositories/65d5559f7c7e2cb9`. To solve that, I guess the following needs to be changed (https://github.com/galaxyproject/bioblend/blob/master/bioblend/toolshed/repositories/__init__.py#L13): ``` self.module = 'repositories' ``` to ``` self.module = 'tool_shed_repositories' ``` p.s. The API key I use is linked to an admin account.

items.title: Documentation inconsistencies
items.body:
So! I was writing https://github.com/galaxy-iuc/parsec and realised that writing wrappers was dumb, so naturally I automated the process. For the command line parameter documentation, I discovered that Bioblend kept really great docs! Thanks y'all! However...there are some minor inconsistencies that I'll be making a PR on soon, but I have a few questions before the PR is completed:
- [`bioblend.galaxy.histories show_history()`](https://github.com/galaxyproject/bioblend/blob/master/bioblend/galaxy/histories/__init__.py#L52) are deleted/visible supposed to be booleans? Additionally, other values for `details` should be documented, or switched to a bool if all/none are the only options. Types is undocumented.
- [`bioblend.galaxy.histories create_history_tag()`](https://github.com/galaxyproject/bioblend/blob/master/bioblend/galaxy/histories/__init__.py#L215) does this really return a json object? Or should that be a dict
- `bioblend.galaxy.histories update_dataset/update_dataset_collection` both take kwds, probably should specify just what goes in there.
- [`bioblend.galaxy.libraries create_library()`](https://github.com/galaxyproject/bioblend/blob/master/bioblend/galaxy/libraries/__init__.py#L13) Does this really return a list? it's a create method...that really seems like it should return a single dict nota  list.
- [`bioblend.galaxy.libraries upload_file_from_server()`](https://github.com/galaxyproject/bioblend/blob/master/bioblend/galaxy/libraries/__init__.py#L224) here it's specified that if folder_id is empty, then the root folder will be used. Is this true everywhere? Should this be an optional param with None as a default? What does roles do?
- upload_file_from_server/upload_from_galaxy_filesystem are confusingly similar, but that's not bioblend's fault.
- [`bioblend.galaxy.libraries upload_file_from_server()`](https://github.com/galaxyproject/bioblend/blob/master/bioblend/galaxy/libraries/__init__.py#L257) what does roles do?

Minor complaint (and goodness knows I'm guilty of abusing `locals()` as well), but several places in the codebase switch between named args, and `**kwargs` automatically passed through. My automating wrapping of all the functions inspect method signatures (since I trust those more than the docs...)

items.title: Tools without input files break workflows.list()
items.body:
I have a workflow that includes a tool that has no input file. This tool creates a file from the input parameters only.

Line 212 in bioblend.galaxy.objects.wrapper.py:

`assert self.input_ids == set(self.inputs)`

Compares the declared inputs to the number of starting points in the DAG. Since this tool has no input files, it looks just like an input file in the DAG layout and gets put into the variable `self.input_ids`. But, it is NOT an input, so the above assertion fails.

I can solve the problem by removing the assertion, but I'm not sure what else that breaks.  The other option is to loop through the inputs and check them in the workflow data. The actual input files should have type set to 'data_input', while the tool should have type 'tool'.

items.title: _wait_datasets not accurate
items.body:
Guys, I see that you monitor dataset status (in galaxy/objects/galaxy_instance.py) with a snippet like this: 

```
        self.log.info('waiting for datasets')
        datasets = [_ for _ in datasets if _.state in _PENDING_DS_STATES]
        while datasets:
            time.sleep(polling_interval)
            for i in xrange(len(datasets)-1, -1, -1):
                ds = datasets[i]
                ds.refresh()
                self.log.info('{0.id}: {0.state}'.format(ds))
                if break_on_error and ds.state == 'error':
                    raise RuntimeError(_get_error_info(ds))
                if ds.state not in _PENDING_DS_STATES:
                    del datasets[i]
```

The problem with with running this immediately after a workflow.run() is that the logic assumes you have access to all dataset statuses while they are still in a pending state. In the event that galaxy is slow to relinquish control of the queuing connection, some datasets may have already switched from a pending state to a failed or ok state. Then your break_on_error is not able to catch those early problems in the workflow, because they are never added to the datasets queue. Make sense?

items.title: Run_workflow is synchronous?
items.body:
Inside the Workflow class (I'm using the Galaxy Objects), I see: 

``` python
      res = self.gi.gi.workflows.run_workflow(self.id, **kwargs)
        # res structure: {'history': HIST_ID, 'outputs': [DS_ID, DS_ID, ...]}
        out_hist = self.gi.histories.get(res['history'])
        assert set(res['outputs']).issubset(out_hist.dataset_ids)
        outputs = [out_hist.get_dataset(_) for _ in res['outputs']]

        if wait:
            self.gi._wait_datasets(outputs, polling_interval=polling_interval,
                                   break_on_error=break_on_error)
```

With wait=False the run() command is supposed to be asynchronous. However, in all my tests, the run_workflow() command is synchronous and does not relinquish control until the last step of the workflow completes or fails. 

How do we get run_workflow asynchronous?
